column1: Jocelyn Lee’s Older Women in the Nude
column3: Is nakedness invisibility’s opposite? Maybe not, but, if it’s unapologetically displayed, it can be a kind of antidote to erasure.

column1: It’s Time for Democrats to Take a Win on Spending
column3: Warts and all, the reconciliation bill would tilt the economy in a greener direction, improve the lives of Americans, and give a boost to Biden.

column1: The Nobel Prize Winner Maria Ressa on the Turmoil at Facebook
column3: Ressa, a Filipino American journalist, discusses the latest revelations of the social network’s failure to control disinformation and hate.

column1: How to React to “Forensic Files” or, Really, Any True-Crime Show
column3: They can show that on TV?!

column1: Eric Trump in Tears After Dad Eats All His Candy
column3: Donald Trump, Jr., had “no idea” why his brother was so upset about the incident. “Dad does this every year,” he added.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Monday, November 1st
column3: “The Fremen really go nuts for these pumpkin-spice lattes.”

column1: Ben Lerner Reads Julio Cortázar
column3: The author joins Deborah Treisman to read and discuss “In the Name of Bobby,” by Julio Cortázar, which was published in a 1979 issue of the magazine.

column1: When the Man in Black Met the Guys in Tie-Dye
column3: Owsley Stanley, the legendary Grateful Dead soundman and LSD chemist, left behind thirteen hundred reels of live recordings from his sonic laboratory, including a newly released recording of the night Johnny Cash came to town.

column1: Maurice Harris Knows What Roses Really Smell Like
column3: The “Full Bloom” judge and florist for Beyoncé and Louis Vuitton talks flowers, tedium, and how fickle the trend of supporting Black businesses can be.

column1: “pencil & pen”
column3: Poetry by Eileen Myles: “A minute is so / long.”

column1: Can Jake Paul Fight His Way Out of Trouble?
column3: A polarizing social-media star seeks an unlikely second act in boxing.

column1: Briefly Noted Book Reviews
column3: “The Morning Star,” “Imminence,” “Things I Have Withheld,” and “Orwell’s Roses.”

column1: Is “Succession” the Best Sitcom on Television?
column3: The HBO series, now in its third season, feels almost Seinfeldian in its efforts to capture a group of eccentric, petty characters as they try, again and again, to one-up one another.

column1: The Mail
column3: Letters respond to an article about the difficulty of defining Long COVID.

column1: When “Foundation” Gets the Blockbuster Treatment, Isaac Asimov’s Vision Gets Lost
column3: The TV version of the classic sci-fi saga sidelines its source’s most pressing questions about power and precarity.

column1: The Most Ambitious Diary in History
column3: Claude Fredericks, a Bennington classics professor, knew Anaïs Nin and James Merrill, and taught Donna Tartt. He kept a journal for eight decades, and persuaded many in his orbit that he was writing a titanic masterpiece. Did he?

column1: “The Haunting of Hajji Hotak,” by Jamil Jan Kochai
column3: Fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai: “You should update your superiors. You should advise them to abort the operation. But you won’t. Not now.”

column1: The Migrant Workers Who Follow Climate Disasters
column3: A growing group of laborers is trailing hurricanes and wildfires the way farmworkers follow crops, contracting for big disaster-recovery firms, and facing exploitation, injury, and death.

column1: Jamil Jan Kochai on Americans’ Fear of Islam
column3: The author discusses “The Haunting of Hajji Hotak,” his story from the latest issue of the magazine.

column1: Work, Motherhood, and Capitalism Onstage
column3: The musicals “Caroline, or Change” and “The Mother” take on personal and political revolutions.

column1: “Last Night in Soho,” Reviewed: A Flashy but Facile Anti-Nostalgia Trip
column3: Edgar Wright’s critique of swinging-sixties London, from the perspective of a young woman of today, gets lost in a tangle of plot twists and shock effects.

column1: As Biden Speaks at the Glasgow Climate Summit, Manchin Muddles the Message
column3: Monday should have been a day of great triumph for America, marking its emergence from the Trump years.

column1: The Risks of Living in This Super-Tall, Ultra-Thin Skyscraper
column3: Please be aware that the physical strain created by the building’s shape produces the following unique (we like to think of them as “exclusive”) conditions.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Tuesday, November 2nd
column3: “If elected, I promise to take down all my campaign signs.”

column1: Republicans Name Joe Manchin Employee of the Month
column3: Kyrsten Sinema, the runner-up, sent her congratulations to the senator from West Virginia.

column1: Will Supply-Chain Issues Ruin Christmas?
column3: Shortages resulting from the pandemic and Brexit are already causing runs on gifts, turkeys, and puddings.

column1: Why Spain Was Long in Denial About Franco—and Still Stands By Columbus
column3: When President Biden proclaimed that Columbus Day would also be Indigenous Peoples’ Day, the right reacted as if the country’s national identity were at stake.

column1: The Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka Discusses His First Novel in Nearly Fifty Years
column3: The Nigerian writer explains the origins of his latest book’s title, why novels are harder to write than plays, and the masochistic pull of political activism.

column1: Expressions More Accurate Than “the New Normal”
column3: It was never normal?

column1: Thirty Films That Expand the Art of the Movie Musical
column3: They’re not all musicals in the conventional sense, but all enrich the cinematic experience of song and dance.

column1: Glenn Youngkin’s Victory Is a Warning for Democrats
column3: The gubernatorial elections in Virginia and New Jersey suggest that Republicans’ appeal to voters has strengthened without Trump.

column1: After a Wild Ride, Eric Adams Takes the Wheel
column3: For Adams, Tuesday included a momentous vote, a P.R. gaffe, and a promise to bring New York together.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Wednesday, November 3rd
column3: “The floor is lava, and without intervention the entire house will be lava by 2050.”

column1: How the Democrats Lost Virginia
column3: The pollster Sean Trende believes that the outcome of the gubernatorial election has less to do with debates about critical race theory than with the economy and the typical disadvantages of the party in power.

column1: Ways in Which to (Safely) Enjoy Fall
column3: Strategies for distracting yourself from the fact that we are somehow still in a global pandemic.

column1: The Velvet Underground Eludes Todd Haynes
column3: The long-awaited documentary about the Velvet Underground is very good, but we had reason to expect more.

column1: The Supreme Court Wonders Where the Texas Abortion Law Might Lead
column3: In order to trample on reproductive rights, S.B. 8 tramples on all rights.

column1: A Celebrity Chef’s Burnout and Pivot to Resiliency

column1: Beyond “Cops”: Other Series-Reboot Plans for Fox Nation
column3: “CSI: Misinformation Unit,” “Young Sheldon Disproves Critical Race Theory,” and other potential reboots for Fox News Media’s new streaming service.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Thursday, November 4th
column3: Enter the gourd vortex.

column1: Uncovering the Secret Offshore Accounts of the Global Élite
column3: In an age of rising populism, the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists is exposing the hypocrisy behind the hidden wealth.

column1: Trump Claims He Is Now Governor of Virginia
column3: He had nothing but contempt for media outlets that have declared Glenn Youngkin the winner of Tuesday’s contest.

column1: How Worried Should Democrats Be?
column3: Do the results of the Virginia and New Jersey gubernatorial races mean trouble for the Democrats in 2022?

column1: An Artist’s Imagining of Life After Humanity
column3: Arjan Brentjes’s film “Sad Beauty” finds an unexpected source of solace in the age of ecological despair.

column1: “A Cop Movie,” Reviewed: A Revelatory Docu-Fiction About Police in Mexico
column3: Working with actors and real-life officers, the director Alonso Ruizpalacios goes where reporters can’t.

column1: We Already Live in Facebook’s Metaverse
column3: Who among us wants to inhabit an even more virtual world of Mark Zuckerberg’s creation?

column1: Biden and Trump Both Lost This Week
column3: Reading the portents of the off-year elections.

column1: Boris Johnson’s Fickle Climate Leadership
column3: In the face of scientific reality, the host of the U.N. climate-change talks comes up short.

column1: Winter Movies Preview
column3: Major movies held over from last year, such as Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story,” join new productions, including Jane Campion’s “The Power of the Dog,” for a teeming year-end calendar.

column1: Fun Ways to Get Spiders on You This Fall!
column3: Go on a romantic, autumnal hike. Or perhaps just clean out your closet.

column1: Winter Art Preview
column3: Sophie Taeuber-Arp makes modernism joyful at MOMA, Holbein builds character at the Morgan Library, the New Museum surveys the illustrious career of Faith Ringgold, and more.

column1: Is This the Worst Place to Be Poor and Charged with a Federal Crime?
column3: The Southern District of Georgia does remarkably little to provide for indigent defendants.

column1: Winter Theatre Preview
column3: Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster in “The Music Man,” Beanie Feldstein in “Funny Girl,” Lynn Nottage’s “MJ,” and more.

column1: Winter Contemporary-Music Preview
column3: Bob Dylan on tour, Kacey Musgraves at Madison Square Garden, Playboi Carti and the Strokes at Barclays Center, and more.

column1: Winter Dance Preview
column3: The tap dancer and choreographer Ayodele Casel’s “Chasing Magic,” new works by Jamar Roberts, Pam Tanowitz’s “Four Quartets,” and more.

column1: Rebecca Solnit on the Politics of Pleasure
column3: The author discusses her new book “Orwell’s Roses” and the role of art and beauty as forms of resistance.

column1: How Colin Powell Saw His Role—and That of Another Famous Non-Quitter
column3: The former Secretary of State, who is being honored at the National Cathedral, had a clear notion of “what serving this nation was all about.”

column1: The Vampy Comedy of “Nollywood Dreams”
column3: The formative era of Nigeria’s film industry, in the nineteen-nineties, is the setting for this new play by Jocelyn Bioh, opening on Nov. 11, at MCC Theatre.

column1: In “Spencer,” Kristen Stewart’s Princess Diana Is Forever Trying Out Roles
column3: Pablo Larraín’s film, less a bio-pic than a set of variations on the theme of Diana, is drunk on the princess’s perception of the world.

column1: At Senza Gluten, the Gluten Isn’t Missed
column3: There are few surprises at this gluten-free Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village, which serves lasagna, chicken parm, and spaghetti alla pomodoro—and that’s largely the point.

column1: Winter Classical-Music Preview
column3: The Met’s New Year’s Eve production of “Rigoletto,” Prototype Festival premières, Death of Classical’s subterranean “Cave Sessions,” and more.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Friday, November 5th
column3: “And then it gets dark outside before you’ve even had a chance to leave the office. . . . ”

column1: The Meta Narrative: What We’ve Learned from the Facebook Papers
column3: Thousands of documents uncovered by Frances Haugen reveal, among other things, how employees of Facebook—or Meta, as it’s now known—talk when they think that no one is listening.

column1: Élitism Without Borders
column3: Some extra-special opportunities for the extra-special few.

column1: Dear Pepper: For Richer or Poorer
column3: There are many people who wouldn’t think that a ginormous wedding gift is awkward and a bit sinister, but I️, personally, happen to agree with you.

column1: How Masai Ujiri Builds a Team
column3: The acclaimed N.B.A. executive on trading players, experiencing injustice, and going home.

column1: The Cryptic Crossword: Sunday, November 7, 2021
column3: Rinses off emergency signals (6).

column1: Sunday Reading: Portraits of Marriage
column3: From the magazine’s archive: a collection of pieces on matrimony and marital trouble.

column1: Running Out of Time at the U.N. Climate Conference
column3: To really appreciate America’s fecklessness, you have to go back to the meeting that preceded all the bad COPs—the so-called Earth Summit, in 1992.

column1: Ways My Dog Keeps Time
column3: Barks per minute, wags per whistle, and other methods.

column1: Why Was the New Jersey Gubernatorial Race So Close?
column3: A pollster for Governor Phil Murphy explains how Republicans nearly pulled off an upset in the Garden State.

column1: The Death of a Sweatpant
column3: After announcing the end of his pandemic-favorite leisure-wear brand Entireworld, the designer Scott Sternberg hits a high-fashion department store to feel some fabrics and rue the price points.

column1: The Book That Taught Me What Translation Was
column3: In its attention to substitution, Domenico Starnone’s “Trust” embodies the joy of moving words from one language to another.

column1: Medicine’s Wellness Conundrum
column3: Patients want alternative therapies. How can hospitals offer them without putting medical integrity at risk?

column1: Explore John Pierpont Morgan College
column3: At the core of a liberal-arts education is the ability to think independently within the parameters of what one’s professors have already said.

column1: “Eternals,” Reviewed: Chloé Zhao’s Lifeless Marvel Movie
column3: With a humanistic tone, the director of “Nomadland” puts substance over style and delivers neither.

column1: The Life and Legacy of Rachel Held Evans
column3: The late author of Christian best-sellers gave voice to a movement of disaffected evangelicals. Will her message outlive her? Plus, Cal Newport on the four-hour workweek.

column1: A Strong Jobs Report Gives Biden and the Democrats a Reason to Hope
column3: Polling suggests that concerns about the economy helped Republicans in this week’s elections.

column1: Cartoon Caption Contest
column3: Submit your caption.

column1: Want to Get Junior Away from That Screen?
column3: Shouts & Murmurs by Jay Ruttenberg: Try martial arts (to wrestle the phone away), a game of jacks, or a time-travel journey to confront the young Steve Jobs.

column1: Eric Drooker’s “The Impossible Dream”
column3: The artist discusses the often quixotic-seeming task of confronting the climate crisis.

column1: A Fearless Experimentalist’s Stealth Reputation
column3: Revered among better-known New Narrative writers, Dodie Bellamy has made uncompromising excess her artistic credo.

column1: Yiyun Li on Friendship and Tolstoy
column3: The author discusses “Hello, Goodbye,” her story from the latest issue of the magazine.

column1: Is the President of Honduras a Narco-Trafficker?
column3: For decades, the U.S. has accommodated corruption in Central America. Now it is contending with the results.

column1: “Hello, Goodbye,” by Yiyun Li
column3: Fiction by Yiyun Li: “Are good choices and bad choices all that different? The consequences of those choices are where life is.”

column1: Thanks for the Bitcoin! How Does It Work?
column3: A quirky Toronto broadsheet, beloved by Justin Trudeau and Margaret Atwood, gets tech support from an Ethereum founder.

column1: Deer Wars and Death Threats
column3: A small subset of wild animals thrive alongside humans. An unusual—and polarizing—set of conservation projects have sprung up in response.

column1: A George Floyd Field Trip
column3: Grade schoolers from P.S. 213, in East New York, took a school bus with Terrence Floyd, George’s brother, to participate in his new lesson plan.

column1: Choose Your Own Kandinsky Adventure at the Guggenheim
column3: “Vasily Kandinsky: Around the Circle” takes the viewer from joy to perplexity—or the reverse—depending on where you start on the museum’s ramp.

column3: The author reads her story from the November 15, 2021, issue of the magazine.

column1: Slide Show: New Yorker Cartoons November 15, 2021
column3: Cartoons from the magazine.

column1: The Great Organic-Food Fraud
column3: There’s no way to confirm that a crop was grown organically. Randy Constant exploited our trust in the labels—and made a fortune.

column1: The Trial of Kyle Rittenhouse Begins with Gruesome Videos and a Plea for Fact-Finding
column3: The rifle-wielding teen-ager killed two men and grievously wounded a third during racial-justice protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin.

column1: “Morning Sun” Glimmers with Meaning
column3: In Simon Stephens’s dreamily extended riff, Edie Falco plays a woman whose life is dramatic but unsung, the kind that never makes headlines but is nonetheless dense with incident.

column1: Briefly Noted Book Reviews
column3: “Oh William!,” “Fight Night,” “Fallen Idols,” and “The Gilded Page.”

column1: “The End of the World,” by Clarence Major
column3: Poetry by Clarence Major: “I look out the window / at a silent dark night.”

column1: Victoria Chang’s Correspondence with Grief
column3: In “Dear Memory,” Chang experiments with the grammar of loss, addressing letters to those who will never respond, and finding meaning in their silence.

column1: What It’s Like to Fight a Megafire
column3: Wildfires have grown more extreme. So have the risks of combatting them.

column1: Parquet Courts on the Dance Floor
column3: A night out in Brooklyn with the psychedelic-punk band’s frontmen, Andrew Savage and Austin Brown, just before the release of their pandemic opus “Sympathy for Life,” which, naturally, was recorded before the pandemic.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Monday, November 8th
column3: “It’s amazing what you can accomplish when you gain an hour.”

column1: Oscar the Grouch Cuts Ties with Ted Cruz
column3: Oscar said that he had supported Cruz’s political career for years “to show solidarity with a fellow-monster.”

column1: “Uppercase Print,” Reviewed: The Terrifying Absurdities of the Surveillance State
column3: The pursuit and persecution of a young freethinker are revealed by way of the archives of the Romanian secret police.

column1: Emily Ratajkowski and the Burden of Being Perfect-Looking
column3: In a new collection of essays, “My Body,” the writer and model reckons with how her appearance has shaped her personal relationships, career, and psyche.

column1: The Splendid Uncoolness of “Sex, Love & Goop”
column3: Gwyneth Paltrow’s new Netflix series, which follows couples who are struggling with sexual dysfunction, is unexpectedly real, and genuinely moving.

column1: Inside the Democrats’ Battle to Build Back Better
column3: House progressives delayed the infrastructure bill to protect Biden’s multitrillion-dollar agenda. Did it work?

column1: Will the Office Survive the Pandemic?
column3: Cal Newport discusses the future of remote work. Even as many offices plan their returns, he predicts that, in the long term, the shutdown will forever change how work is done.

column1: Computer Functions I Wish I Had in Real Life
column3: The wonders that a search bar and autocorrect can bring to the analog world.

column1: Text Messages to Which I Will Never Receive a Response
column3: How was space? We missed you down here, ha ha.

column3: “Is there a doctor or anyone who has done their own research on board?”

column1: Why Andrew Roberts Wants Us to Reconsider King George III
column3: The conservative writer, who counts George W. Bush and Henry Kissinger among his admirers, discusses imperial nostalgia and his new book about the maligned monarch.

column1: “Passing,” Reviewed: Rebecca Hall’s Anguished Vision of Black Identity
column3: With a remarkable fusion of substance and style, Hall’s adaptation of Nella Larsen’s 1929 novel unfolds inner lives along with social crises.

column1: Trust Is Hard to Find at the U.N. Climate Summit in Glasgow
column3: Young activists are right to doubt the pledges of governments, financial firms, and the fossil-fuel industry.

column1: On “Still Over It,” Summer Walker Gets the Last Word
column3: Like Keyshia Cole and K. Michelle before her, Walker traffics in an argumentative form of R. & B., itemizing misdeeds, lamenting wasted time, and putting the men responsible on notice.

column1: The Question We’ve Stopped Asking About Teen-Agers and Social Media
column3: Should they be using these services at all?

column1: The Aging Anarchist’s Cookbook
column3: Sections on making drugs and explosives have been removed. Can you imagine having the energy to do anything like that?

column3: “Holding superstar quarterback accountable—token penalty after the kickoff.”

column1: Kayleigh McEnany Tells January 6th Panel She Never Worked at White House
column3: “For the past five years, I have been assistant manager of an Enterprise Rent-a-Car branch.”

column1: Does Xi Jinping’s Seizure of History Threaten His Future?
column3: The struggles of the first century of Communist Party rule are being buried by the need to cohere around what Xi calls “the great rejuvenation” of China.

column1: A Choir at the Crossroads of Boyhood and Manhood
column3: The documentary “The Voice Break Choir” features a Swedish ensemble that lets teen-age boys keep singing as their voices—and lives—change.

column1: A Doctor, a Patient, and Their Poetry
column3: In some ways, writing was the best treatment.

column1: “It Just Hurts a Little Bit, and It Helps You”: New York City Kids on Getting Vaxxed
column3: On Monday, at a Manhattan public school, students ages five through eleven put on their brave faces and looked forward to life after the shot.

column1: Questions My Tarot Cards Refuse to Answer
column3: “Will my neighbor ever get the hint?,” “Why does the M.T.A. schedule feel like a personal attack?,” and other imponderables.

column1: Louise Erdrich’s Spectral Novel of the Moment
column3: In “The Sentence,” Erdrich takes on COVID-19, the George Floyd protests, the effects of incarceration, and a haunted bookstore.

column1: Welcome to Your Decided-Not-to-Have-a-Baby Shower!
column3: It’s going to be a challenging first couple years as you power through the remainder of your thirties with people constantly asking when you’re going to procreate.

column1: The January 6th Investigation Gets Closer to Donald Trump
column3: Judges, national-security officials, and Liz Cheney say that the effort must proceed.

column1: How Trump Transformed the Supreme Court
column3: The legal journalist Linda Greenhouse expects the new conservative majority to change American law on abortion, religion, and affirmative action.

column1: Philip Montgomery’s Up-Close Portrait of an America in Crisis
column3: For nearly a decade, the photographer has been chronicling the country’s historic struggles, with an intimacy that can be achieved only by getting uncomfortably close.

column1: The Selfish Individualism of Aaron Rodgers
column3: The Green Bay quarterback’s semi-rebellious attitude once seemed almost charming. But his attitude toward the N.F.L.’s vaccine mandate has exposed his self-absorption.

column1: What Does an At-Home Abortion Look Like in 2021?
column3: The practice is often assumed to be dangerous, but Abigail Aiken’s data suggest that ordering abortion pills online, and inducing a miscarriage at home, is as safe as going to a clinic.

column1: Politics and Justice at the Kyle Rittenhouse Trial
column3: A Wisconsin jury considers “the most divisive case in the country.”

column1: Daily Cartoon: Thursday, November 11th
column3: “What do I get for the person who has everything, because he buys it for himself right before the holidays?”

column1: “The Hare with Amber Eyes,” at the Jewish Museum
column3: Japanese netsuke—ivory carvings used as kimono ornaments—are at the heart of both the Edmund de Waal memoir and the show, opening Nov. 19.

column1: Magic Mushrooms, a Love Story
column3: A graphic novel tells the story of the couple whose love for fungi and each other laid the foundation for the serious study of psilocybin.

column1: A Middle Eastern Party at Shukette, in Chelsea
column3: The chef Ayesha Nurdjaja’s eclectic menu includes an exceptionally rich labneh, Moroccan bread topped with whole roasted garlic cloves, and reliable char-grilled pleasures such as the Persian-inspired Joojeh Chicken.

column1: Hi, I’m Your Best Friend Who Can Rationalize Anything!
column3: When we prioritize ourselves it empowers those around us. I read that on Instagram.

column1: Richard Rusczyk’s Worldwide Math Camp
column3: Online, a math Olympian has found a way to nurture prodigies from around the world.

column1: Daily Cartoon: Friday, November 12th
column3: Fall foliage, as seen by man’s best friend.

column1: Future Lana Del Rey Albums
column3: “The Born-Again-Virgin Suicides,” “Proud Boys on the Potomac,” “The Real Queen of Detroit,” and other astonishments for your ears.

column1: The Essential Workers of the Climate Crisis
column3: If the roof is ripped from your house or the basement is drowned in mud, these are the people you’re looking for. Who’s looking out for them? Plus, Anna Deavere Smith in her own words.

column1: Ted Cruz Gets to Sesame Street
column3: The senator from Texas draws the ire of Big Bird and company.

column1: The Diasporic Mélange of “Nollywood Dreams”
column3: Jocelyn Bioh’s comedy is set in Lagos in the nineties, during the upsurge of off-kilter, melodramatic cinematic invention that, in the decades since, has helped make Nigeria an engine of global entertainment.

column1: Europe’s Migration Crisis, Born in Belarus
column3: “Europe’s last dictator” won’t hold on to power forever. But he has invented a new weapon.

column1: Sunday Reading: The High Stakes of Infrastructure
column3: From the magazine’s archive: a selection of pieces about how issues of infrastructure have altered the fate of American cities, towns, and lives.

column1: The Cryptic Crossword: Sunday, November 14, 2021
column3: Facial hair has to hurt (8).

column1: The Vaccine-Mandate Battle
column3: Vaccines work, and so do mandates—but Aaron Rodgers and Republican politicians are among those who are muddying the message.

column1: Wait, but Have You Tried—
column3: A rib belt? Kinesio tape? Cupping? Do you wear a brace for it?

column1: Lin-Manuel Miranda Goes in Search of Lost Time
column3: The “Hamilton” creator’s directorial début, “Tick, Tick . . . Boom!,” channels the bohemian life and spirit of the theatre composer Jonathan Larson.

column1: How Britney Spears Got Free, and What Comes Next
column3: Spears fought for years to end the conservatorship she was under, and finally won. But the legal battles aren’t over.

column1: Discovering the Oldest Figural Paintings on Earth
column3: While working as an independent archeologist, an Indonesian grad student revised the human story.

column1: Nightmare of the Windowless Dorm Room
column3: Charlie Munger, a Warren Buffett crony, donated two hundred million dollars to a university for a gigantic new dorm. The catch: no windows. How did guinea pigs in a similar Munger housing experiment fare?

column1: Credit-Card Perks for Castaways
column3: Start earning the minute you wash ashore.

column1: Bruce McCall’s “Season’s Special”
column3: The artist discusses his favorite city-dwelling rodents and how he learned to appreciate animals from his daughter.

column1: The Complex Task Facing the Kyle Rittenhouse Jury
column3: ​​The panel may consider lesser charges when determining whether the teen-ager committed crimes or acted in self-defense.

column1: Davóne Tines Is Changing What It Means to Be a Classical Singer
column3: The bass-baritone’s daring recitals feel almost like compositions in themselves.

column1: “Detective Dog,” by Gish Jen
column3: Fiction by Gish Jen: “When the Hong Kong police stormed the universities, she and her family just sat here in New York on their lilac leather couch and watched on their computers.”

column1: Petey’s Earnest Songs and Absurd TikToks
column3: He has become famous online for silly and sweet comedy videos. Now fans are discovering his music.

column1: How Your Family Tree Could Catch a Killer
column3: Genetic genealogists like CeCe Moore are cracking cold cases and transforming policing. As DNA analysis redefines ancestry and anonymity, what knowledge should we be permitted to unlock?

column1: How the Week Organizes and Tyrannizes Our Lives
column3: From work schedules to TV seasons to baseball games, the seven-day cycle has long ordered American society. Will we ever get rid of it?

column3: Cartoons from the magazine.

column1: Welcome to the Police Station, How May We Help You?
column3: A new batch of recruits spends a day training to be N.Y.P.D. community guides—like Walmart greeters for police precincts—as part of the department’s new customer-service push.

column1: “Kaepernick,” by Sasha Debevec-McKenney
column3: Poetry by Sasha Debevec-McKenney: “The football players / are kneeling because, I say, anyone could kill / your Black son.”

column1: Gish Jen on Storytelling Across Cultures
column3: The author discusses “Detective Dog,” her story from the latest issue of the magazine.

column1: “Former Lives,” by Carl Dennis
column3: Poetry by Carl Dennis: “It can lead to the practice of tolerance, the notion / That the soul returns to earth more than once.”

column1: Can Russia’s Press Ever Be Free?
column3: The journalists of Novaya Gazeta report on dangerous conflicts—and endure threats of their own.

column1: How Kristen Stewart Became Her Generation’s Most Interesting Movie Star
column3: The actor’s naturalistic style is captivating to some and inscrutable to others. As Princess Diana in “Spencer,” she takes on the biggest role of her career.

column1: A Voice for the Yorkies and Doodles When Mom and Dad Split Up
column3: Matthew Cooper, a New York matrimonial-court judge, reviews his landmark canine cases (including one decision citing Lassie) after the passage of a New York law allowing the court to consider the welfare of pets in divorce proceedings.

column1: Welcome to Mars! Frequently Asked Questions
column3: Shouts & Murmurs by Nicky Guerreiro and Ethan Simon: Of course there’s air! Just don’t breathe it. And, with the crazy gravity situation, everyone can dunk!

column1: The Hard Choices of Elizabeth Hardwick
column3: Behind the renowned prose, there was a writer constantly weighing the costs of freedom and submission.

column1: Maggie Gyllenhaal and Girlfriends Channel Elena Ferrante

column3: Her soul got kicked out of Fleetwood Mac and was asked to rejoin Fleetwood Mac and was kicked out again.
